holidays.name: International Day of the Teddy Bear
holidays.description: A day dedicated to celebrating the cuddly, beloved teddy bear that has warmed hearts worldwide.
holidays.origin: Inspired by the creation of the teddy bear in the early 1900s, this day encourages people to share the joy of their favorite teddy bears.
holidays.funFact: The teddy bear was named after U.S. President Theodore "Teddy" Roosevelt, who famously spared a bear cub on a hunting trip.

holidays.name: World Children's Day
holidays.description: A day to promote international togetherness, awareness among children worldwide, and improving children's welfare.
holidays.origin: Established by the UN in 1954 to promote the welfare and rights of children globally.
holidays.funFact: World Children’s Day was the day the UN adopted the Declaration of the Rights of the Child in 1959.

holidays.name: Absinthe Day
holidays.description: A quirky day celebrating the famously mysterious and once-banned "Green Fairy" spirit called absinthe.
holidays.origin: Observed in various countries on November 20, marking the end of absinthe prohibition in some regions and its cultural impact.
holidays.funFact: Absinthe was popular among famous artists like Van Gogh and Toulouse-Lautrec, who called it 'the green muse.'

holidays.name: National Peanut Butter Fudge Day
holidays.description: A deliciously sweet day to indulge in creamy, dreamy peanut butter fudge treats!
holidays.origin: An unofficial food holiday spreading sweet enjoyment among peanut butter lovers.
holidays.funFact: Peanut butter fudge recipes date back to the early 20th century, blending two American favorites—peanuts and sugar!
